page.title: 11LANGUAGE
page.content: The Norfolk dialect is a very distinctive one with its own vocabulary and grammar. Sadly however, since the last century it seems to have been the language of the uneducated and no one of any standing in society speaks it nor uses its vowel sounds. This is probably because it is associated with country folk, traditionally looked down upon by their urban cousins. In recent years the dialect in Stanhoe has changed markedly especially among the young. The distinctive vocabulary with the young has almost gone. What remains, except among the over fifties, is an amalgam of near cockney speech plus some Norfolk expressions - 'in a muddle,' 'get wrong' are examples. It is doubtful if true Norfolk will be heard in future years.
